Dear Sir,

I have been informed today that Chief Shabnimiki has sent in a request for seats for the White Fish Lake School. I beg to state that in my opinion and that of some others of the Band, it is an unnecessary expense. The seats and chairs are made of wood and strong and in every way suitable for the school. Consider that there are other articles which we stand in more need than these seats. Farming implements, for instance. The Chief did not consult me in this matter nor any of the councillors. Therefore I strongly object to such unnecessary outlay of our funds.

Yours truly,

(sgd.) Jas. Robyette,
Second Chief
Indian Office, Winnipeg, October 23rd, 1893.

Sir,

I have the honor to report that Chief Waheminiak of the White Fish Lake Band has applied for 20 new seats and desks and one Teacher's Desk for the School House at White Fish Lake. The desks asked for are such as are supplied by Messrs A McGill and Son of Chatsworth Ont., and cost $3.50 for Seat and Desk and $7.00 for Teacher's Desks. The number is more than is required for strictly School purposes, but as the School House is used for Church purposes and also as a Council room the quantity applied for is not too great.

Enclosed is a communication from the second Chief who objects to the expenditure being incurred.

I respectfully recommend that the Indians should be instructed to hold a Council and decide the matter of the Seats and Desks by a vote.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Deputy Superintendent of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of official letter dated 30th October relative to the application of Chief Wahominike of the White Fish Lake Band for 20 new seats and desks, and beg respectfully to state that the present seats are an uncomfortable pattern for the children, and they have to write at a table which is not nearly as convenient as the seats and desks combined as applied for by the Chief. I do not consider that the school house is properly and commodiously furnished for school purposes—the number applied for by the Chief is more than is required for strictly school purposes. The number of children attending school being 18, I respectfully recommend that in combined seats and desks and one teacher's desk be furnished to the school in question.

Montreal, Oct. 25th 1878

My dear,

In my recent visit to the Indians, I visited the school at Pointe-aux-Sables. The school was in the midst of the Indians' settlement on the Attawapiskat River, a distance from the nearest settlement village, and school, and therefore presented better educational advantages for their children. I was very impressed with its size and purpose at Pointe-aux-Sables. It was not a large school, but its size was adequate. The school was very near Pointe-aux-Sables and the people are few. Consequently, they choose they might all live at Pointe-aux-Sables. But the fact remains that families have gone to Attawapiskat, and are living there; and some of children belong to this little settlement, Attawapiskat, and it would be well for them to attend school. As it is now, we have no school facilities.

I wrote today the case before the Department and asked what view they take of the case. Are they disposed to build a school for the people and give the necessary work? And with the amount of the school at Pointe-aux-Sables divided into two, in some way, if it is willing between the two schools?

Again I must venture to urge the Board of Education at Pointe-aux-Sables, to S. Ferriar, whose name is always on whose petition is usually written, should receive $250 per annum instead of $200.

Yours faithfully,

George Atkinson

[Signature]

P.S. Dear Sir,

I am writing this letter to you because I believe it is important that the Board of Education at Pointe-aux-Sables should consider the possibility of building a new school. The current school is not sufficient for the needs of the community, and I urge you to take action to address this issue.

Sincerely,

George Atkinson
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, 12th December, 1898.

THE SECRETARY,

With reference to the application of His Lordship
the Bishop of Algoma for the opening of a school for a
portion of the Indians of the Whitefish River Band who
have located at a point four miles from Birch Island
on the Whitefish River, north side of the Georgian Bay,
I have the honour to state that there is no present a school at Birch
Island under the auspices of the Church of England.

According to the report for the September quarter received
from the teacher, Mr. S. H. Perris, there are 11 children
in attendance, with an average attendance of 4. The
salary, which is voted, is $200.

In his annual report Superintendent Ross does not
mention the portion of the Band settled at the point in
question. Speaking of the Band generally he says:
"The Indians have a good school and the general profi-
ciency of the pupils is satisfactory".

If the school at Birch Island, which has been es-
tablished for some years at a point suitable for the
majority of the Whitefish Band has an attendance of only
4, it is hardly likely that a new school for the conve-
nience of only a portion of the Band would have a suffi-
cient attendance to warrant its being established.

H.C. Ross
Exd.

Ottawa, 24th December, 1898.

Right Reverend Sir:

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of Your Lordship's letter of the 25th ultimo, in regard to the establishment of a second school for the convenience of six families of the Whitefish River Band who have settled on the Whitefish River four miles from the school at Birch Island.

In reply I have to say that as the school already established at a point suitable for the majority of the Band, although in operation for some years, has only 11 pupils or the roll, with an average attendance of 4, it is not considered likely that a second school will attract attendance sufficient to justify its establishment.

I regret, therefore, that the Department does not see its way to increasing the number of schools for the Whitefish Band at present.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Your Lordship's obedient servant,

J.M. Molson

Rev. C. Thorpe, D.D.,

Pimicopurst,

Bult Ste Marie, Ontario.
Exd.

George Algoma

I have the honor to report that I visited the Whitefish River Reserve on the 22nd Instant, in which the question of erecting a new school on the surrendered portion marked No.5 on the main land, on the said reserve.

There are 8 families living on this Reserve, in which includes 19 children of school age, and they are members of the following Bands:

Whitefish River Band:
- Widow of John Mitchell's 2 children school age,
- John Kashikgobenese 1 do

Sucker Creek Band:
- Esquimaux George 4 do
- Flijah 4 do
- Abraham 2 do
- Simon 3 do
- Wilson 1 do

Non treaty Indians:
- Oliver Henry total 79 do

The Indians are anxious to have a school opened after mid summer if possible, as these children are neglected and growing up without any chance of receiving an education.

If the Department declines to erect the said school for the Indians, no doubt the Bishop will do so with the consent of the Department, and that he be given the deed of the land for the school site, which is selected at the north of the Whitefish River on the surrendered portion of the Reserve, marked No.5.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
As nearly all of members of the Whitefish River Band reside at Birch Island, which is six miles from the purposed site, they object to any of their funds being used to pay for the building of the said school, and maintain, that only two of their members reside at Whitefish River, while the others are members of the Sucker Creek Band, and one is a non-treaty Indian. The Bishop wishes a reply at an early date, so that action may be taken in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

OTTAWA, April 7th, 1922.

Dear Chief,

Replying to your letter of the 3rd instant, I beg to inform you that the building at McGregor Bay, on the Whitoflan River Reserve, used for school and church purposes, was erected during the summer of 1890. Sir,

A communication has been received from Chief Wm. McGregor, of the Whitefish River Reserve, in which he states as follows:

"Lately a man came and ordered the schoolhouse to be closed and prevented the members of the band from holding our council meetings and informed us that the old schoolhouse was sufficient to hold our council meetings."

Sir:

In reply to Official Letter of the 7th ultimo, in regard to a complaint made by Chief William McGregor, of the Whitefish River Reserve, that the schoolhouse was ordered to be closed and prevent members of the band from holding their council meetings, and in reply I have the honour to report that I visited Whitefish River and made inquiries in the matter and found that there are two Indian members of the Anglican church who object to the holding of council meetings as they claim that it was erected for a schoolhouse and church and not a building to hold public meetings where the Indians eat and smoke and muss the floor and furniture, and do not assist in scrubbing or cleaning after their council meetings.

I might also say that I could see that some of the Anglican members felt that the Roman Catholic members were trying to impose upon them by trying to force them to open the building they have in use for a church for to be used in future for to hold council meetings, etc.

It does not appear to me that there should be any objection to their using the building for council meetings if the Indians who attend conduct themselves properly and not disturb the furniture.

My dear Mr. Scott:

Ever since I became Bishop of the Diocese of Algoma, twenty-six years ago, we have had the use of a small building at Birch Island, part of the Whitefish Indian Reserve. The Indians at that point are divided between the Church of England and the Roman Catholic Communion. There is a disposition at the present time to claim the building for use by the band as a council chamber. This is not at all satisfactory to us, as it interferes with our use of it for religious purposes. Will you kindly tell me the history of this building, and what rights the Church of England has in it. One of the oldest residents declares that the materials were provided by the Church, and that it is to the best of his knowledge and belief a church building. Of course, if it is a Government building the Department has a right to determine what its uses shall be; nevertheless, after so long a period of use, some clear and generous rights should belong to the Church of England, her use of it having been unbroken through the period referred to. Will you kindly let me have an answer at your earliest convenience.

Believe me,

Very faithfully yours,

George Algoma

Sir:

I am in receipt of Official Letter or the 4th instant, in regard to the report made to the Department by His Grace the Archbishop of Algoma in reference to the building at Birch Island which for some years past was used as a combined church and school, and in reply I have the honour to report to the Department that His Grace must have been mis-informed in this matter as the Indians do not wish to rob the building of its semi-sacred character, they only ask the privilege of holding their meetings or the council in the building as they have not any other place to meet in council. After each council meeting the building has been cleaned and everything left in perfect order.

I might say for the information of the Department that it is not the Indians that want to use the building for council meetings only, but if it is the missionaries that are trying to prevent the Indians from holding any council meetings in this building and wish to use it for church purposes only, and the teacher in charge of the school at Whitefish River, who is acting as an Anglican missionary among the Indians, has gone so far as to lock the building in order to prevent the Indians from making use of it for council meetings.

As far as I can see there should not be reason why the building should not be available for the use of the Missionary for church services and the Indians for meetings of council, and the Indians are perfectly willing to abide by that decision.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Lewis:

As I have already informed you we are started, and are carrying on by means of Church funds a little day School at White Fish Falls for combined groups of white and Indian children, neither of which is adequate of itself to justify a school. Sir:

I am in receipt of Official Letter No.19-IO-5 of the 5th instant, relating to the report of Mr. Lucius Handyman with reference to a building at Whitefish Falls which he requests the Church authorities to occupy inside, but they do not feel like spending money on this building unless its use by the Indians for Council meetings is discontinued.

In reply I have the honour to report that the building referred to by Mr. Handyman is the old Anglican school building at Birch Island in the Whitefish River Reserve which was formerly in use as a Church and School building.

This building is situated on the Whitefish River Reserve and was erected by, and kept in repair, by Departmental funds. It has not been in use for school purposes during the last twenty years past, but the Anglican Church authorities have used it regularly for Worship, and the Band use it to hold their council meetings as they have not any other building for that purpose.

As the Indians have not any other building to hold their meetings, and this building is Departmental property, and after each meeting the Indians clean the building thoroughly also conduct themselves properly; therefore, I cannot see why the Church authorities should object to the Indians holding their council meetings in this building.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. McGill,

I want to call your attention to the situation of the Catholic Indians of the Christian Island Reserve, a situation which has been of long duration but of which I was not quite familiar until some months ago. There are on the Reserve about three hundred and fifty Indians, of whom about one-third are Catholics. There is one school, at which I think sixty children are registered, and of these twenty-eight or thirty are Catholics. There are two teachers, both Protestants, and the Principal is a minister of the United Church.

I made enquiries about a month ago at your Department and was told that, insofar as the Department knew, there was no Catholic school on the Christian Island Reserve, but only a school conducted by the United Church. This is a situation which will have to be remedied.

I am very reluctant to cause any difficulty or any embarrassment, and I am aware that the funds of the Indian Department are at a very low ebb through the need of the practice of rigid economy. By rights, of course, in accordance with the Indian Act the Protestants should have their school and the Catholics theirs. This would necessitate the building of a new school.

However, if the Department preferred and the United Church authorities concurred in the arrangement, we should be satisfied for the present, and as a temporary expedient, to have a joint school for Protestant and Catholic children. But we should have to insist that one of the teachers be a Catholic and that the Principal be not a minister of the United Church.
Keep the baby warm and dry. Do not let any old woman or anybody kiss it on the mouth or handle it much.

Be sure that every small child gets some fresh food, meat, fish or soup or berries or canned tomatoes.

TORONTO...August 28, 1934

Very Reverend Father Kingston, Provincial of the Jesuit Fathers who have charge of some Indian Missions in the Archdiocese of Toronto, has placed before me correspondence that has passed between and the Department of Indian Affairs regarding proper provision for education of Catholic children on the Christian Island Indian Reservation.

From what information I have before me, it would appear that no provision at all has been made for these children of our Faith, and that, if they would have any schooling, they are compelled to attend a school in which both teachers are Protestants and one is a Minister of the United Church.

I am quite sure that the late Archbishop of Toronto, who made such a fight for Catholic education, had no knowledge of the state of affairs in Christian Island, and that he would never have acquiesced in their continuance.

I confidently look to an immediate remedy of a situation that is wrong and contrary to the law, now that it has been pointed out to you.

I am,

Yours truly,

Sir:

I have received this morning a letter from Honourable T. G. Murphy, Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, advising me that instructions have been sent to the Department "to provide a teacher of the Roman Catholic faith at the Christian Island School".

In the course of our conversation in the office of the Superintendent General on Wednesday last, September 12th., Mr. Murphy seemed strongly of the opinion that it would be better to separate all the children by religions, placing all the Catholic children under the Catholic teacher and all the Protestant children under the Protestant teacher. He thought this better than separating the children according to their grades; giving the lower grades to one teacher and the upper grades to another.

Father Labelle, our missionary at Christian Island, called to see me this morning and he is very strongly of the same opinion, namely that the children should be separated according to religion rather than to grade.

MEMORANDUM

The Honourable the Superintendent General -

Mr. Sutherland, head of the Schools Branch, has furnished me with the attached memorandum with respect to the school situation on Christian Island.

The series of transfers outlined by Mr. Sutherland would seem to present the only feasible solution of the difficulty. You will note, however, that it will entail Mr. Carruthers accepting a salary less than the one he is now receiving, while the salary of Mr. Morris, transferred from Christian Island to Oneida No. 2 school, will be increased by a corresponding amount, i.e. $50.00. I would respectfully suggest that we have your approval of the scheme outlined.

Mr. Sutherland is of the opinion, in which I concur, that the arrangement the least likely to cause friction is the separation of the children into two class rooms according to their respective religious faiths; that is to say the teacher at present at Christian Island would teach the children from the Protestant homes in the school building, and the new teacher transferred would teach those adhering to the Roman Catholic faith in the Council Hall.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I had a visit this evening from Rev. Father Labelle, the Jesuit missionary to Christian Island. He is, by the way, a graduate of St. Michael's College, Toronto. He came to me soliciting my aid in obtaining some urgent necessities for the new school on the Island. Miss O'Toole arrived there yesterday and on finding no school or equipment and no provision made for a teacher's residence practically broke down. However, she sent a message to me containing a list of the more essential things needed. I would judge from this that she is ready to stick it out for a while anyhow. I understand that the order was that school would be held in the Council Hall. The Catholics, however, were prohibited from using it so they intend to use the church which can be made satisfactory for the time being. There are 25 children in attendance and the old single desks are allowed their use. There is no blackboard or equipment of any kind, only a few pieces of chalk given the teacher. I am enclosing on a separate sheet the equipment that is urgently needed.

There is a stove in the church but about 3 lengths of pipe are needed immediately. There is no wood for fuel. I think you will have the Indian agent assist you for this. Finally, there is a Catholic Indian named for caretaker at the council room. I think he was to be paid $75.00 for the year. He should be instructed to transfer his duties in the making of fires to the church. This is urgent. The missionary with some of the Indians built toilets (outdoor) this morning. These will have to be paid for but the cost will not be very much.

The teacher is going to live with the Indian agent for a while. I understand that he is new to the Island. I think he is a decent fellow. I think his wife will like to have this teacher with her but the walk to the school will be over a mile and in winter time the winds and the snowdrifts may force her to live in the back of the church, and if so then this small room would need a kitchen stove, a bed and bedding, a kitchen table and chairs, a Coleman lamp, and the usual cooking utensils and dishes.

The teacher could live in the Jesuit Missionary's house which is close to the church but it is entirely devoid of furniture of any description. I might say here that the 25 children are crowded into the 2 small rooms of this house for school today until the church can be made suitable for occupation. The missionary needs about 6 weeks.

Of the grievances affecting the members of the Christian Island Band of Indians re-Educational System, as set forth in this document, to wit:

Dear Mr. McGill,

I want to call your attention to the situation of the Catholic Indians of the Christian Island Reserve, a situation which has been of long duration but of which I was not quite familiar until some months ago. There are on the Reserve about three hundred and fifty Indians, of whom about one-third are Catholics. There is a school, at which I think sixty children are registered, and of these twenty-eight or thirty are Catholics. There are two teachers, both Protestants, and the Principal is a minister of the United Church.

I made enquiries about a month ago at your Department and was told that, in so far as the Department knew, there was no Catholic school on the Christian Island Reserve, but only a school conducted by the United Church. This is a situation which will have to be remedied.

I am very reluctant to cause any difficulty or any embarrassment, and I am aware that the funds of the Indian Department are at a very low ebb through the need of the practice of rigid economy. By rights, of course, in accordance with the Indian Act the Protestants should have their school and the Catholics theirs. This would necessitate the building of a new school.

However, if the Department preferred and the United Church authorities concurred in the arrangement, we should be satisfied for the present, and as a temporary expedient, to have a joint school for Protestant and Catholic children. But we should have to insist that one of the teachers be a Catholic and that the Principal be not a minister of the United Church.

We are anxious to do everything that is reasonable and to avoid all expenses that are not absolutely necessary.

With kind regards,

I am,

Dear Sir,

I acknowledge receipt of your letter no. 6-1-1, dated August 20th, in reply to mine of July 25th.

Why this report from the Indian Agent was not asked for during the four weeks that were allowed to elapse between my letter and your reply I fail to understand. Moreover, it is not at all a question of my wishes, but of the clear rights of the Catholic Indians, which are completely disregarded and set aside.

After lack of information, the lateness of the season is given as a second pretext for deferring the matter, though the delay is due in no small part to the fact that my letter remained unacknowledged for nearly four weeks. I telephoned to your Department a week ago and proposed to go to Ottawa to see you, but was then informed that the matter was in the hands of the Minister.

The matter cannot be allowed to drop. I have tried to be courteous and conciliatory, and am much disappointed that this attitude has not been appreciated.

On several occasions I have had to exercise patience with what looked like an anti-Catholic bias in the Department of Indian Affairs. This is an ugly charge to make and I have never made it up to the present, but if required I will produce instances from within my own experience. But in none of these instances has this bias gone to the extent of a direct and evident and complete disregard of the rights of the Catholic Indians, and I refuse to believe that the Indian Department will care to go on record as anti-Catholic.

In my letter of August 30th addressed to the Honourable the Minister of the Interior and Superintendent of Indian Affairs and in my letter of the same date to the Deputy Superintendent I stated that I had received instructions from the Right Reverend Monaghan Carroll, Administrator of the Archdiocese of Toronto, to advise the Indians through their missionary that they were not to attend a school that was purely a Protestant school, and so long as it remains an exclusively Protestant school. With the permission of the Administrator I have withheld that notification until now in the hope that it would not prove necessary, and in order to allow the Department to do the fair and proper thing.

The Department seemingly has not appreciated this, and unless I hear immediately I shall feel bound to act without further delay.

I asked that a telegram be sent to me today in Toronto or tomorrow in North Bay. Failing this I shall go to Ottawa in a final endeavour to obtain justice, and also to avert a most unpleasant and deplorable situation.

I am,

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I have received this morning a letter from Honourable T.G. Murphy, Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, advising me that instructions have been sent to the Department "to provide a teacher of the Roman Catholic faith at Christian Island School".

In the course of our conversation in the office of the Superintendent General on Wednesday last, September 12th, Mr. Murphy seemed strongly of the opinion that it would be better to separate all the children by religions, placing all the Catholic children under the Catholic teacher and all the Protestant children under the Protestant teacher. He thought this better than separating the children according to their grades; giving the lower grades to one teacher and the upper grades to another.

Father Labelle, our missionary at Christian Island, called to see me this morning and he is very strongly of the same opinion; namely that the children should be separated according to religion rather than to grade. In this way friction will be avoided and both parties will be satisfied. I hope this will be done.

I am sorry to say that the missionary's house which I said we would offer to the teacher will prove too cold for her occupancy, once the cold weather sets in, but Father Labelle says that the teacher will have no difficulty in finding quarters near the school in the house of one of the families. The Department can count upon our fullest cooperation in the matter.

Very sincerely yours,

(Sgd) W.H. Kingston, S.J.

Dear Leonard:

It is also with regret that I have received your note of 16-3-42. I have read the contents several times and have endeavored to fathom the perturbed state of your mind.

First of all, let me congratulate you on the English you have used in your letter and the courteous manner in which you have expressed your feelings. It is not always that Mrs. Cowan and I have received notes so noticeably courteous.

I shall try to explain on paper the incident in question, as it appeared to me and as it occurred.

It would seem that this winter most of the irregularity of attendance reported from Miss Elford's room has been in regard to the boys. The girls, as a general, seem to be very anxious to attend. As yet I have not succeeded in discovering altogether just why the boys are not as anxious to attend as the girls.

On several occasions Miss Elford reported to me certain absence and in most cases I suggested that she herself write a note to the parents.

It so happened one morning that I was just passing the School on my way to the Office, when Miss Elford shouted to me that two boys were running away from the school through the bush. The children were being called in to school; when I inquired who they were, I was told that Junior and Charlie King had gone. On a previous occasion when I had asked Simply for the reason of absence of his boy, he told me that they should not be absent as they were sent from home. He asked me to bring a little pressure to bear on them for playing truant. With this in mind, I concluded that there was no alternative but to act at this time. Accordingly I sent a bigger boy to bring them back. While waiting I broke a switch from a bush. I did use the switch on them a couple of times as they ran ahead of me to the school. As you have intimated, the boys were more frightened than hurt. I feel quite safe in saying that I am certain your boy would have been dealt with more severely by you as parent had you caught him on a similar occasion.

We all know of course that reports are somewhat exaggerated and understated at times. However, the very fact that your boy did not report to you seems evident to me that he did not suffer severe punishment. The snow was fairly deep and the boys ran just far enough ahead of me so that I could not have used the switch unduly even if I had desired to do so. It has always been my policy to maintain reasonably strict discipline but I have never been guilty of using severe methods except as a last resort. This incident was not a last resort and the punishment employed was not severe.

I discovered later that one of the older boys had been telling Miss Elford certain untruths concerning Junior. I recommended that boy strongly for his false reports. This was done in Miss Elford's classroom during school hours as a means of letting all children know that such false reports would not be tolerated.

I had not heard anything further concerning the incident and dealings until Sister Black reported to the Agency Office that Junior was in attendance at the R.C. School. She asked me if it was permissible for pupils to transfer at will from one school to the other. I appreciated Sister Black's cooperation in this respect and I wrote a note to her to the effect that such procedure was contrary to School Regulations and Department Rules.

Extract from Acting Inspector J.E. Morris' report of his inspection of the Christian Island Agency dated June 23, 1948. Original on file 77-6 Ins.2.

R.C. Day School.

This school is in good condition. The residence and class room are constructed on a cement foundation. The Superintendent advised that authority has been obtained to purchase storm windows.

The present enrolment is 22 and is expected to increase to 27 when the school opens in September.

The desks in this school are also in a poor condition. I would recommend that 28 new type desks be authorized - 10 small, 10 medium and 8 large. The attendance on July 18th showed only that five children were at school - 11 had gone berry picking.

The annual migration of the Indians from the Reserve during the berry picking time is seriously affecting our school attendance during the last two weeks of June, as noted above. The thought occurred to me why not cut down the Christmas and Easter holidays or possibly start school earlier by opening in the autumn one week sooner. I understand the schools are supposed to commence on September 7th. If they are started one week earlier, then the class work could be arranged so that school would be closed on June 15th, or thereabouts and get in the full school year.

Ottawa, September 28th, 1934.

Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 12th instant, I beg to say that it has been decided to provide a Roman Catholic Indian Day School on the Christian Island Reserve. By establishing this school, only one teacher will be necessary in the Christian Island United Church Indian Day School. Consequently, as you will note from the enclosed letter, Mr. Vernon H. Morris is being transferred to the Oneida No. 2 Indian Day School. You should give him every possible assistance in carrying out the instructions contained in the enclosed letter.

The Roman Catholic Indian Day School should be conducted in the Council Hall and the United Church Indian Day School in the present school building. The latter school, of course, will continue in charge of Rev. Fr. Dean and Miss M. M. O'Toole, who has been teaching at the Lower French River Indian Day School in the Barry Sound Agency, is being transferred to Christian Island and will be in charge of the Roman Catholic Indian Day School at a salary of $80 a teaching month.

Miss O'Toole is being instructed to reach Penetanguishene on October 13th. The Department desires you to meet her there and take her to Christian Island. Please write Miss M. M. O'Toole, Lower French River Indian Day School, Pickering, Ont., informing her at what point in Penetanguishene you will meet her on the 13th proxime.

The children of those Indians who are recognized as Roman Catholics must attend the Roman Catholic Indian Day School, while the children of those Indians who are recognized as Protestants must attend the United Church Indian Day School. Children must not be transferred from one school to the other without first receiving the consent of the Department.

The Department understands that the Roman Catholic Church authorities will make arrangements to secure suitable boarding accommodation for Miss O'Toole.

The Department expects you to give every possible assistance to the teachers of both schools in your agency.

Your obedient servant,

John A. Allan, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Christian Island, Ont.

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

Attention of Mr Phelan,

Dear Sirs,

I wish to confirm the assurance given already verbally that we shall place without charge the missionary's house at the disposal of the Catholic teacher on the Christian Island Indian Reserve for the present year at least. As I am relinquishing office within a very few days, I do not wish to make any long-term promise, but I am sure that if the Department does the proper and generous thing, my successor can be relied on to do the proper and generous thing also.

Yours very truly,

W.J.H. Hamilton, F.J.
Provincial, Jesuit Fathers of Upper Canada
He has a list of the necessary furnishings needed and when advised to go ahead with the repairs he will arrange to have the teacher accompany him to Penetang to select the furniture and kitchen utensils. He has been advised that only good serviceable articles should be purchased and the cost kept as low as possible.

It might be advisable to have the assurance of the Church authorities that the Priest's Residence will be available for a teacher as long as it is required for this purpose, otherwise it would seem unwise to expend the money on it.

I might say that Miss O'Toole appears to be a very conscientious and efficient teacher. Under very unfavourable circumstances she has entered into the work cheerfully and with determination to make good.

[Signature]
Inspector.

I was requested by the Schools Branch to look into the question of class room accommodation, equipment and living quarters for the teacher.

The school has just recently been established and is being conducted in the R.C. Chapel with 28 pupils enrolled and desk accommodation for 18. Additional seats are required as follows -

- 8 for pupils 7 to 10

- 3 = 13 to 15 also the following equipment and supplies -

Teacher's desk
chair

pipe

Living quarters for teacher. A very neat little cottage known as the Priest's Residence is available for use of the teacher just across the road from the chapel. Father Labelle assured me he had the necessary authority to hand it over for this purpose as long as the need existed. Approximately $200.00 would have to be spent to make it comfortable as teacher's residence. The foundation should be banked with earth; windows and doors tightened up, the torn door at the entrance, a bedroom partitioned off, the walls and ceiling painted and floors covered and a chemical closet installed. Agent Allen can arrange for a local Indian to do the carpenter work and painting.
not exceed the figure mentioned above.

After this work is completed, you should forward accounts, in triplicate, covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of materials, and a voucher, in triplicate, properly certified, for the amount due for labour.

The Department will leave this matter in your hands, to make the best arrangements possible and at the lowest cost, to have the living quarters fitted up for the teacher of the R.C. School.

I may add that an order will be placed here for the supplying of 18 school desks, of the size required, and a teacher's desk and chair for the use of this school. This equipment will be shipped, addressed to you at Penetanguishene, Ont. When the shipment arrives, you should have the articles taken to the school and set up in the classroom. Any expense in connection with the transfer and installing of the desks will be paid upon receipt of a certified voucher, in triplicate.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, November 12, 1934.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McGeekin, who recently visited Christian Island, reports regarding the fitting up of living quarters in the Priest's residence for the teacher of the Christian Island R. C. Indian Day School. The church authorities have given assurance that they will place this house at the disposal of the Catholic teacher, without charge.

The Inspector recommends that the foundation be banked with earth and the windows and doors tightened up. He recommends that a storm door be installed at the entrance, that a bedroom be partitioned off, the walls and ceiling painted and floors covered and also that a chemical closet be installed. He states, further, that you could arrange for a local Indian to do the carpenter work and painting and that you have a list of the furnishings required.

I have therefore requested that you will arrange, at the earliest possible date, to have the work, as mentioned by the Inspector, performed, in order to provide comfortable living quarters for the teacher in the Priest's residence. The Inspector states that you will arrange to accompany her to Penetanguishene, to select the furnishings and kitchen utensils. He states that approximately $200.00 would cover all costs for repairs, etc. It is hoped that you can have the work mentioned performed, employing Indian labour - the materials to be purchased by you. February 7, 1935.

Memorandum:

CHRISTIAN ISLAND R.C.

To erect new school building with teacher's living quarters for R.C. Indian children - $6,000.

The above amount is provided in the Estimates, 1935-36, for the erection of a new school building for the Catholic Indian children on the Christian Island reserve. The building will require classroom accommodation for 30 children, and further, living quarters should be provided for the teacher. Outside toilets would also be required - one for boys and one for girls.

No doubt, Indian labour could be utilized to a large extent in the work of erecting the building.

No arrangements for a suitable site have yet been made. The Indian Agent could, no doubt, obtain the consent of the Band to provide a site, of approximately one acre, that would be level and with good drainage.

September 14, 1935

The Secretary,
Dept of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont., Canada.

Dear Sir,

I inspected the Christian Island Catholic School this past week. The report will reach you later but there are a few urgent matters.

1. There is no wood at the school yet, nor does it seem to be out. Burning green wood in the cold winter days is a trying situation. There is only 1 cord at the school and none at the teacher's residence. About 1/2 a cord of the Mission Church wood has been used. This must be returned. There is no kindling wood for the teacher's use and she is finding it difficult starting fires with slabs of hardwood.

2. Duncan Copegoz has been caretaker of the School since January. To date, he has received only $7.00. This should be investigated. This man has been most faithful. During last winter he had difficulty keeping this church-school heated. Many times he arose in the middle of the night to make sure the fires were on. He has washed the floors once a month. Mowed church benches and school seats weekly. He should be paid $50.00 yearly.

3. Complaints reached me also that John Sylvester, caretaker for the Fall term of 1934 (October, November, December) was not paid at all. He was officially engaged. Nothing was paid him. It should be investigated and allowance paid him so that there are a lot of hard feelings existing over it.

4. Since the school being held in the church an allowance should be made for rent to the missionary. At least $10.00 a month for the church for school purposes and $5 or $7 a month for the missionary's house used by the teacher since last October 1934 and that is real cheap. I might say that the missionary had to change the windows and add to them five lights for school purposes. Four windows (2 1/2 each) about 4' x 3" were specially made. Besides one of the stained glass windows was broken and all glass should be made. This is the usual wear and tear where children are, which should be paid for.

5. Kindly hurry along the new school and residence combined.

6. The teacher is without lamp light. She has a fine Aladdin Lamp but she needs mantles. Send 6 mantles for Aladdin lamp and 2 chimneys for this new type No. 12.

All of which is respectfully submitted.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

J.M. Bennett, M.A.
Inspector of Separate Schools

Ottawa, February 21, 1936.

Dear Sir,-

With reference to your letter of the 10th instant, the Department has received a request in the past for the erection of new schools on the Christian Island Reserve.

It is noted from your letter that you have been informed that the Catholic Church will not be available for school purposes after June 30th, next.

However, at the present time, the Department is not in a position to state definitely whether or not funds will be available for the erection of new schools on the Christian Island Reserve during the coming summer. The matter will be kept in mind and given further consideration after the first of April, when our appropriation for the next fiscal year is available.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Dear Sirs:

May I call your attention to the situation of the Catholic Indian School on Christian Island. I refrained from writing you until the present time, hoping from day to day that the situation would be remedied. I wish to remind you of the following points:

(1) That your department has been using the Church for a School and the Missionary's House as a residence for the School Teacher and no rental has been paid for either.

(2) The continual daily use of the Church by the thirty-two Indian children has caused much unavoidable wear and tear which the Department should pay for; chief of which is a new front door; inside swing door tightened and painted; the broken windows replaced and the woodwork around the lower interior painted; the eighteen benches painted. (The continual moving and piling of the seats and kneeling benches, each week, to make room for the school desks has somewhat damaged them).

(3) The outside toilets were erected by the Missionary at his own expense. He also had extra windows put in the Church to light it better for school purposes, although his revenue is a mere pittance.

(4) The house itself is in need of paint.

(5) I wish to also point out that for two year, the Missionary has been put out of his house and has occupied temporary quarters in a small room at the back of the Church. He never thought that the Church and house would be used by the Department for over two years. Cannot something be done to hurry the building of the School?

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 28th with further reference to the new combined Day School and Residence I beg to advise you that the foreman's wages are to be 70 cents per hour.

Dear Sir,

I would like to ask if there has been any decision as to the heating system of the new H C School. Is it to be a furnace or just stoves? Would not a wood burning furnace similar to the one at the agency be the more economical? It would heat both residence and school; I would like permission to buy point to drive for water. In the basement of school while digging cellar struck water and have been able to have all needed for building purposes right there but the trouble is it is right in center of floor which would be a very inconvenient place. Can get water at the north west corner leaving the center of floor clear and it would be right under kitchen and if a sink is to be in it could be quite easily piped to it. Mr. Geo. A. McLean, M.P., writes me under date March 21st, as follows:

"I have a letter from the firm who supplied the material to the contractor who built the school and residence at Christian Island for the Indian Department last fall, advising me that on the date he wrote Mr. Laurin had not received final payment for his contract.

March 29, 1939.

Dear Mr. McLean,

I have your letter of the 21st instant in which you advise that, according to the firm who supplied building material to Mr. Fred Laurin, contractor on the day school and teachers' residence at Christian Island Indian Reserve, the latter has not received final payment for the work done under his contract.

This work was handled by the Surveys and Engineering Branch of this Department and the Director of that Branch advises me that final payment was made to Mr. Laurin by cheque on February 18th last. Mr. Laurin's security deposit was returned to him by cheque on March 7th last, together with accrued interest of $2.40. No doubt by this time Mr. Laurin has received both these cheques.

Yours very truly,

W.J.V. Pratt,
Secretary.

George A. McLean, Esq., M.P.,
House of Commons,
Ottawa.

I am forwarding herewith a draft reply for Mr. Pratt's signature and am also returning Mr. Pratt's memorandum to you.

Respectfully submitted,

J. M. WARDLE

Dear Phil:

I think I have done everything to assure a safe arrival for the Sisters on Christian Island. I wrote Dr. Tanner to kindly see to their transportation to the island. I wrote to the Acting Indian Agent that Dr. Tanner had been written to this effect. I also told Rev. Father Lebel in case he wished to be on hand to welcome them. I advised them to get a grocery order from Eaton's etc etc. They will arrive by train at Ponctang on Wednesday November 19th at 1:05 p.m. with two trunks and hand baggage.

I spent about an hour with them today and gave them all the information I could. They are two very admirable ladies in talent and personality. The teacher has had some 12 years teaching experience in the Province of Quebec (holds a Superior certificate). The Indians are going to have the benefit of real inspiration.

I got a reply from Miss O'Connell regarding some matters about the house. There is only one bed upstairs and the couch in the living room. After the Sisters arrive and when I view the situation we will let you know whether or not another bed should be provided.

Will the Dept supply another Alladin Lamp? and a gallon can of oil can't be a two gallon one would be better.

The Sisters would like to have a sewing machine provided. It would be of great value because already these Sisters have discussed with me the course of study for the older girls and planned covering classes for older girls. I would strongly advise providing them with a sewing machine (second hand if no other could be obtained).

Would you please supply the following for the course in sewing and knitting:

- Spools of thread - a dozen of each of white and black at $40.
- Sewing needles - assorted packages.
- Knitting needles - a dozen pair.
- Crochet needles - six.
- Cotton wool for mitts, etc for knitting - 2 lbs of Grey, 2 lbs of red and two lbs of blue.
- Or any factory cotton - 24 yds or so.
- Ordinary cotton poplin - 24 yds in different colours as follows:
  - 3 yds red and 3 yds of yellow-blue
  - 5 yds green
  - 9 yds rose
- Cotton flannel - this is sold in skeins they would like:
  - 6 skeins of each of these colours: red, green, blue, pink, etc.
- Ordinary gray flannel - could you send them a bolt which is about 24 yds and is cheaper that way.
- Cotton tape - 12 rolls (3yds to roll) this is cheap.

They can give a real contribution to the Indian girls life with this sewing course. I don't think the above requisition is excessive. The sister who will do this is expert.

If your printing office has a text on the household arts sent to other schools, send one here.

Sincerely,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

In accordance with the request of your Department to my Chief Inspector, I made a special visit to Christian Island School on November 25th., 1941. The day was fine, following a snow storm but the water in the channel was running high from the southwest and the spray from the white caps sure did drench me somewhat. It was a rolling trip.

As I intimated in my letter to you earlier, they will need another bed. There is room in the bed room for a single 3' 3" bed. They will need a mattress to go with it. They also have need of a few kitchen supplies. There is no wash tub nor is there anything big enough to cook a ham; no bread pan either. Some cooking will be taught these girls. These I am also listing on the enclosed sheet together with the cost as shown in Eaton's Catalogue. Eaton's have evidently trucked some presents with someone in Penetang and orders are delivered direct to the Island, free of transportation charges. So maybe it might be best to deal with them.

The Sisters attended the Sunday service which the Catholic Indians hold on Sundays when the missionary is not there (which is most of the time). The prayer man attends to this. At his request they held open house in the school in the afternoon and all went pleasantly. From what I learned from Capegog, who took me across, they are quite pleased and happy for the provision your Department has made for them in giving them the Sisters of Service. The House of Arts of Sewing, etc., which the housekeeper will give them will evidently be most welcomed. She is very capable. The sewing machine is not there as yet. But the transportation of it will be the problem of the Indian Agent.

I hope you will be able to supply all of the enclosed.

The Sisters said that a cheap cot would do them but that is not such a "hot" idea to me. What do you think?

I felt that this initial order should be sent you direct rather than through the agency since these have to be decided upon.

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

J. M. Bennett.
I understand that you have trucking arrangements with someone in Penetanguishene and that orders are delivered direct to Christian Island. It would, therefore, be appreciated if you would arrange to have the above items shipped at once to Sister Ames V. Black, Teacher, Christian Island R.C. Indian Day School, Christian Island, Ont. Your account, in triplicate, should also be forwarded to Sister Black who, on receipt of the goods, will certify the account and forward it to this Department for payment.

Dear Sir:

I was called to inspect the H. C. School one day this week. I found that the water seeps in through the floor and an inch or so of water lays on the floor nearly all the year, in fact Sister of Service Black, told me that at some time there is considerable water on the floor of the basement.

Upon checking on the situation I am of the opinion that the school is built on the ravine which the seepage follows from Lake Douglas, which is about quarter of a mile from the school itself.

If my hunch is right then the only solution to the problem is to tile across the North end and down the west side which would require 300 feet of tile.

I did not ascertain the cost of tile, and will await your instructions before doing anything further.

The labor would cost about 30 to 40 Dollars.

Mr. C.E. Hurl, Acting Indian Agent, Christian Island,
Ont.

In reporting on his inspection of the Christian
Island R.C. School on May 28, Inspector Bennett writes:

"Water flooded the cellar to a depth of eight
inches. A tile drain will no doubt help, but will
this not freeze in the winter? The main cause is the
way water comes up through the thin cellar floor. It
is such a fine cellar that I would suggest that
another concrete floor be made over it. The island
is full of gravel and they have a mixing machine."

The Department is inclined to feel that the
trouble with this school is that no gravel bed was
provided under the cement floor to allow water to run
away. It is possible that in order to make a proper
job it will be necessary to remove the present cement
floor and put in a gravel base and then a new cement
floor. I should appreciate it if you would give this
matter your immediate consideration and let me know
the probable cost.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
The Secretary Indian Affairs Branch Dept., Mines & Resources

In reply to yours of June 30th, file no. 6-2-5 regarding report of Inspector Bennett.

You will recall that we done some work on this school last fall, and completed it this spring, in that we put a tile drain along one end and one side carrying it about one hundred feet beyond the school property towards the Bay, this drain done a very good job in taking the water out of the cellar. I am inclined to believe that this school was built right over the natural outlet or seepage of Lake Douglas, and this I am sure is the cause of the water coming into the cellar in the spring of the year. I have also ascertained from the Indians that there was a foundation of stone laid before the cement was put down.

I know from going to the school several times last spring, that it is anything but a nice situation, having the water in the cellar, and is certainly not healthful, but I am at loss to know what can be done further to overcome the difficulty.

If you deem it advisable that we should lay another coat of waterproof cement, of perhaps two inches thick, on the floor and carry it up the walls for a height of about 6 or 8', I will have this done, may I suggest that it be left for Mr. Arnall to consider when he comes back this fall, as I understand he is coming then.

Acting Indian Agent
G. M. Hurl.

I have pretty well completed the cellar drain job at the R.C. School. And this job is going to cost about $100.00. I had to buy 60 feet more tile, and even yet if I am going to continue the drain down to the drop in the rise of the ground it will be necessary to put in some box drain to do this.

After putting a drain all the way around both sides of the foundation, outside, and then filling it in the water still raised on floor of the basement, so there was nothing left to do but to dig a drain right across the floor through the cement floor and lay tile in this, I was then able to overcome the difficulty. Right now the floor is dry, and here is hoping that it will remain that way.

Mr. Arneil and I discussed this proposition from every possible angle; he suggested that I should try and get some contractor or builder to come out and give expert advice this I tried to do but could not get a man to come. So there was nothing left for me to do but to go ahead, which I have done.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa

We should do something about the painting of the outside of the two Indian day schools on the Island.

I see no reason why the Indians could not do this work; there are several quite capable of doing the work. May I order the paint, and employ the Indians paying them 35¢ per hour to do the job.

There is another matter which should be attended to, that is the heating system in the U.C. school. The hot air pipes lead through the wall from the main basement, there being a hole just large enough to allow the pipes to go through. It is here that I feel that the difficulty arises. I am quite sure that it will bind.

I have been called to the school in the winter when the rooms have only been 40 degrees, with a good fire on in the furnace, this means quite a fuel loss.

May I be permitted to have a plumber come and check on this with the idea in mind of repairing it if possible, or should I have them give us an estimate of the cost?

G. E. Hurl,
A/Indian Agent.
Ottawa, July 12, 1946.

Mr. G. R. Hurl, Indian Agent,
Christian Island, Ont.

I have your letter of the 5th instant, with reference to painting the outside of the two schools on the Christian Island Reserve. How much paint would be required and what colour do you suggest?

I note that you can secure Indians at $5.00 an hour. What amount would be involved for labour? The Department requires the above information before making a final decision regarding the painting of the buildings.

You may have a plumber examine the heating system at the United Church School, with a view to remedying the condition which you mention.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa

Replying to your letter of July 12th file 6-2-5 regarding the painting of the two Island schools.

As near as I can estimate we will need 10 gallons of (cream) paint for each school, 1 gallon (cream) for each school. Then I believe that 1 gal. of oil, and 1 gal. of turpentine should do both. I will also need some brushes.

I could recommend that we give the work two coats, as they are in very bad shape.

I have arranged with the Indians to do the job, and I estimate that it will take 3 to 4 days to do the U.S. school, and 7 or 8 days should do the M.C. school. In estimating this I have taken into consideration that two men would be employed. This would mean that the U.S. school would cost about $70.00, and the M.C. school $50.00 and $80.00. This being for labour only.

Regarding the heating system at the U.S. school I had a slower time out, and he referred to me that the only sure way of overcoming the difficulty is to put a wall around the building. He is quite sure, as I have already reported, that this is the cause of the air not getting through the registers. This would run into a considerable cost; the kiln wing under which the foundation is needed, is about 4' x 24'.

G. H. Earl,
Indian Agent.

Indian Day School Regulations

All Indian schools shall be kept open for not less than 200 days in each year.

Schools shall be opened after the summer holidays on September 1st unless this date should be Labour Day, and shall close for Christmas holidays on December 22nd.

The winter term will commence on January 3rd and run June 30th in each year.

The following holidays will be allowed before the year—Labour Day; all Saturdays; Christmas Day; New Year's Day; Good Friday; Easter Monday; the remainder of the week following Easter Monday; King's Birthday; Dominion Day; Canada Day; Thanksgiving Day; Remembrance Day; Armistice Day; Victoria Day; and the first Monday in August.

In addition to the above, the Roman Catholic Schools may allow as holidays a limited number of holy days of obligation, not exceeding five in all, which will be observed as teaching days and for which payment of salary will be allowed.

There is the intention of the school board to make recommendations for the observance of these holidays during the summer (two months) only. Upon the recommendation of the local Agent, it is intended that no change is to be made without the express approval of the Department.

The remaining session shall be from 9 a.m. to 12 noon and the afternoon session from 1 p.m. to 4 p.m., with a recess during each session of not less than 15 and not more than 20 minutes.

Teachers of teachers will benefit by a holiday of ten (10) working days at the end of each school year.

Sick leave will be granted at the rate of two weeks per year, or such shorter period as may be necessary.

Salary will be paid at the end of the quarter, except in cases where the school has been closed for more than one month.

All teachers will be required to give at least one month's notice of their intention to resign.

All questions relating to the day school should be referred to the local Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Henison:

A little while ago I received a letter from Mr. Smith, the Indian agent at Sioux Lookout containing the following paragraphs:

"Before you complete arrangements for a school at Picton Lake next year, I would suggest that you get in touch with our department and ascertain if they will authorize the operation of a school there in 1948. I understand very few Indians are to be employed with the mines and if such is the case, I believe the school would serve more children and be better for the future...I recall of the Osnaburgh Land and if it were located at the reserve (on Lake St. Joseph).

You will rather from this that he is apparently not in favour of the school at the Landing. Why? I do not know. The above reasons do not seem logical to me. The school is by no means for children of those who work in the mine in particular. From local inquiry I am convinced that the school would not serve more children if it were on Lake St. Joseph. Mr. Swartman sees the Osnaburgh Indians at Treaty Time, when, naturally they are all on deck to receive their four dollars. Normally, I understand that there are not many together in one place on Lake St. Joseph for any length of time during the summer. With regard to his supposition re "welfare and morals", I do not know what the inference is. I have heard no complaints.

Last Summer our attendance at the Landing reached twenty-four and there would have been more if transportation could be arranged for those at the Crown. Of those who did attend I am of the opinion that very few were connected with the mines. A number were with Forestry and for this work will be living at the Landing each summer. I doubt if any were with the mine. I understand that it would be difficult to get any number of children
three years. Mr. Bridle has every qualification as a teacher. He holds a B.A. degree, and is a qualified school teacher in Ontario. I have received a request from the owner of the building that the Church should buy it. The building is not a church, but a school, and I would be very glad if we could make some arrangement whereby we could pay for the school as soon as possible.

It may be necessary for me to go to England next summer, and I would like to know what arrangements I could make with regard to the following schools:

1. Mistassini -
2. Waswanipi
3. Lansdowne House
4. Fort Hope
5. Pickle Crow Landing

I understand that the school and teacher's house for Mistassini and Waswanipi are either finished or will be finished next spring.

I expect to be in Ottawa on April 14th and 15th, and I would like to talk over the question of our policy with regard to these schools. In the meantime, I want to secure the teachers for next summer. There are one or two other places, besides Pickle Crow, where the question of a school building should be considered.

Yours faithfully,

Robert J. Renison

Ottawa, April 5, 1913.

Right Reverend Sir,

Referring to Your Lordship's conversation with the Superintendent of Indian Education I beg to say that the Department is ordering to be sent into Canaburg a supply of biscuits for the children attending the day school. These will go forward from Winnipeg.

At the same time Your Lordship mentioned the need of some repairs to the school and if you can give the Department a list of the materials necessary these also can be sent in.

I would draw Your Lordship's attention to the very small average attendance at this school since it was opened. During the September quarter it was only 5.2 and during the December quarter one. In view of this and the possibility that the school may not be continued it is not considered advisable to make any extensive repairs. I shall be pleased to hear from Your Lordship further at your earliest convenience.

I have the honour to be, Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean

Dear Sir,

I enclose several requisitions for the summer schools at Big Fish River and Maclean's Falls.

Regarding Maclean's Falls, I may say that I have seen applications several times during the past year, and I am sure a school could be started there very easily, even without further information.

However, last summer, a school at Big Fish River was successful, and we believe that Maclean's Falls, too, would be suitable for a similar school. This request, which was so kindly made by our missionary, Rev. Edward Hinchliffe, at Big Fish River, under whose supervision the place is, and who gave me the information that at least 20 children of school age are growing up in that district, without any chance for education, surely deserves your attention. Frequently, he asked to build a teacher and was fortunate enough to secure another student from St. Paul's College, Winnipeg, Rev. W. D. Hudson, whom I am sending to Maclean's Falls next summer. John G. Anderson
Diocese of Moosonee
A request has been received from His Lordship the Bishop of Moosehead for the opening of a school for the summer months at Harten's Falls. He compares the conditions at this point with those at English River, where a school was open last summer from May 1st to August 31st. The pay list shows that there are 77 children at Harten's Falls and the Bishop states that there are at least 25 of these of school age. He states that he has been fortunate enough to secure the services of a teacher, Mr. A. J. Anderson, a student from St. John's College, Winnipeg, to carry on the work. Mr. Avery informs me that there is a church building at this point and, no doubt, the school would be conducted in that building.

His Lordship also requests that the school at English River be re-opened next summer. The cost of this school for the past summer was as follows:

- Teacher's salary: 4 months
- Rent of building: 4 months
- Stationery and school supplies

The school at English River, from reports received, seems to have been successful, having had an enrolment of 57 pupils, with an average attendance of 25.

I would be pleased to recommend that the school at English River be re-opened and that a trial be given during next summer to the work of conducting a school at Harten's Falls. The expense of carrying on the work at these points during the summer will be about $250.00 at each point. This is the only opportunity the children have of receiving any education.

Davis of Nepigon in which that gentleman offers the use of the church for school purposes at Long Lake, which is situated east of Nepigon and north of Jackfish on the C. & R. Applications have been made for a school at this place since 1894, but as yet no provision has been made. The last census gives the population of the Long Lake Band as 630: 61 Anglicans, 268 Roman Catholics and 1 pagan. The number of children of school age is shown to be 93. Mr. Hodder says that the probable attendance if a school is opened at that point would be 12 during winter with a larger number in the summer, and that he would like very much to see a school established at this place.

If the Department considers this application it would be necessary to provide an amount for the teacher's salary and also a small sum for making the building warm enough for winter use. I do not say what amount would be required for this purpose, but I think $75.00 or $100.00 would more than cover the necessary outlay.

Former applications have been endorsed by the Hudson's Bay Company's Officers, the Roman Catholic Missionaries and our Agents.

My dear Mr. Pedley:

I heard there is some question of building a school at Long Lake for the Long Lake band of Indians. I was at Long Lake last summer and spent about a week there.

This is a nomadic band, almost entirely uncivilized. They are in the forest from October to May. In summer they are about the lake fishing and picking berries. I am certain that they could not be persuaded to send their children to school, if a school and teacher were there. Besides, it would be impossible to get a teacher of any kind of qualification to go and stay there. There are many Indian schools much more accessible and much more congenial for a teacher than Long Lake, which are vacant, because teachers cannot be found who are willing to go to those places.

I am solicitous for the educational and moral welfare of the Indians, but I must in conscience advise the Department against the expenditure of money for schools in places where they would produce little or no good.

Yours very devotedly,

D. J. Scollard,
Bishop of S. S. Marie.

Dear Sir:

At a point along the Canadian National Railway, east of the town of Hornepayne, about twelve miles, is a settlement of Protestant Indians numbering about 70 souls. It is what was formerly known as the Skunk River, now known as Morrison River.

These Indians are cross, and formerly belonged to Albany River. I think they are now paid under the Long Lake Band, in the Fort Arthur Indian Agency. They are mostly composed of the families of George Taylor "A" and George Taylor "B", and others who have married into them.

There are about twenty children of school age at this place, and the people reside there for the greater part of the year.

About a month ago when I was up at that point, George Taylor "A" asked that a small school be erected and a teacher supplied. He stated that he could assure an attendance for fully nine months of the year, if the school was kept open during the summer months.

As you are aware, there is no reserve at this point, but these Indians have been located here, and have had their trapping headquarters here for several generations. The Hudson's Bay Company has a small trading store here, kept by one of the Taylors, and there are three or four fairly good Indian houses.

The people are very badly in need of instruction in various ways and appear to require the protection that a fair, good teacher might be able to give, against the class of white men who usually infest such localities.

The place is beautifully situated, and quite easy of access, at all times of the year, being only a short distance down the river from the regular flag station on the C.N. Railway.

I would very strongly recommend that one of your "Improved Schools" be erected at this place, where the Indian children would not only be taught to read and write, but other things, which are quite as essential for the welfare of these people.

Trusting that these suggestions may meet with your careful consideration,

Believe me,
very faithfully yours,

Rev. Prewer
Ottawa, August 12th, 1924.

Rev. Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant, requesting, on behalf of a number of Indians residing at a point known as Morrison River on the Canadian National Railway, the establishment of a day school for the benefit of their children.

In reply I am to say that these Indians belong to the Martin's Falls Band Reserve at Long Lake. They are hunting Indians and do not live on their Reserve but wander around the country, hunting, and are never a sufficient length of time in one place to educate their children. The Department cannot establish a school off a Reserve, and, as these Indians do not reside on their Reserve, we are not prepared to consider their request to establish a day school.

As you state the parents are anxious to have their children educated, a number could no doubt be placed in the Chapleau Indian Residential School. I shall be pleased if you will endeavour to persuade the parents to allow their children to be sent there. The Chapleau School can no doubt accommodate a number of these children. Owing to the nomadic habits of these Indians, it is considered that a day school would not be satisfactory on account of the irregular attendance, and, therefore, the placing of the children in the Chapleau School would be the best means of their obtaining an education.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Dear Sir,

I wrote the Department, sometime ago, suggesting that a small day school should be carried on at this place for the 20 or more children of school age. The Department did not approve of the plan; stating that it were better, since there was room, to send them to the Chapleau Boarding School. I wonder when the Department and the Church, are going to see the unkindness of such a move. To send children, when we are sure they are affected, into the midst of what ought to be, a bunch of healthy pupils, such as ought to be in our schools, is little short of murder. It is bad enough when they are admitted and develop the disease afterwards, but to take them there to have them die and affect the others is too serious a matter, if it is merely to say we have our schools full.

Surely the Department cannot but view the ravages this disease has made amongst the pupils of the Chapleau School during the past three years without very grave concern. I believe I am right when I state that since I gave up the Principalship at the end of March 1923, no less than 22 who were then on the roll have either died in the School or at their own homes or at some Hospital from this disease. I think I can also safely say there are three or four more that will die. With a knowledge of these conditions, it is small wonder that the authorities find it difficult to persuade the Indians to send their children to the Boarding School.

Geo. Prewer.

MEMORANDUM

When recently attending the Treaty Payment at Long Lake, Ontario, my attention was drawn to the necessity of a Day School at that Reserve. There must be at least forty (40) children of school age running wild with no instruction or restraint upon them, and the necessity of a School there was apparent.

These Indians live the year around on their Reserve close to the Canadian National Railway Track at which point the Transcontinental trains stop, and the Indians are much in evidence.

The School buildings erected at Pic, Sand Point and Gull Bay Reserves are splendid ones, and a credit to all concerned in their construction. At present one is being erected at Hobert, and I hope one for Long Lake will be provided for in next year's Estimates and erected next Summer.

These school buildings will also afford a comfortable stopping place of the Travelling Nurse. In fact without them there would be no place for her to stop a few days on these Reserves, and with the co-operation of the School Teacher, great benefit will accrue to the Indians as the proper kind of school teacher can help the nurses considerably in seeing that her instructions are carried out when she leaves the reserve. Mr. Burk is endeavouring to secure teachers with this end in view. At Long Lake the School Teacher for the Travelling Nurse in co-operation with the School Teacher., The School Teacher at Gull Bay last Winter and Spring did wonderful work. I hope to see a School building under construction next year at Long Lake.

HONOURABLE THOMAS G. MURRAY,

I wish to inform you that Mr. J. G. Burk, Indian Agent, Fort Arthur, Ont., has strongly recommended the providing of school facilities and the appointment of a teacher for the benefit of the Indian children of the Martin Falls band, residing on the Long Lake reserve, No. 77, in the Fort William agency. These Indians reside at Long Lake during the summer months, where they have constructed 15 log houses, and they cultivate land and grow vegetables. In the winter months, they move to Harrison River, to be near their trapping grounds, where they have erected a church and also 15 substantial log houses. Harrison River is not on a reserve but is situated near the line of the Canadian National railway, approximately 150 miles north and west of their reserve.

The Agent requests that a classroom be fitted up at each of these points, school supplies furnished and a teacher appointed - the school to be conducted at Harrison River during the winter and at Long Lake during the summer. There are 30 children of school age, who are not at present receiving any education. These Indians are Anglican.

Mr. Burk has been informed that at the present time there are no funds to equip classrooms and provide teacher's salary but that consideration would be given to the establishment of a school when possible to provide funds for the purpose.

In submitting the above for your information, I feel assured of your approval for the establishment of a school for these Indian children when funds are available. No provision was made for this school in the Estimates for Indian Education for the coming fiscal year - the request of Agent Burk not having been received previous to the preparation of the Estimates.

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.

Feb. 27th 1934

Dear Sir:

I have been receiving letters from the Chief and other Indians of the Parry Sound Band and now from our missionary, Rev. W. Balsberg, concerning a need for a school for his many children who have no educational advantages whatever. I know the Band of Indians well and they are very progressive and feel very keenly the want of schooling for their children. As an example of the progressiveness of this band, I mention the fact that they built a church themselves at Morrison River entirely at their own expense. Indians like these should have encouragement; they offer to provide a building for school purposes at Morrison River for the winter months when they reside at that time, because it has been a starting place in their hunting grounds. In many cases and also because there are no fish and they will have to be moved to some place. All they could need would be a supply of school material and, of course, a teacher. A school could be built on the same premises in summer. I believe the matter was brought before the Indian Agent and he promised or stated expected had wished would have been provided this winter at Morrison River, but I am told that nothing has been done so far. I trust you will give this request prompt attention so I consider it a worthy one.

Sincerely,
