May 2nd, 1935.

Dr. McGill,

The authorities of the Church of England have requested that a day school building, with living accommodation for a teacher, be established for the benefit of the Indian children of the Martin Falls band, residing on Long Lac reserve, No. 77, Fort William agency, Ont. Mr. Agent Burk, Port Arthur, states that the school should provide accommodation for approximately 36 children.

There are no funds specially provided to cover the cost of erecting the building, but there is an amount of $4,000.00 provided in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year, to erect a day school at the Rabbit Island settlement, on the Manitoulin Island Unceded Reserve. The need for a school at this point is not as pressing as on the Long Lac reserve, and I would recommend that the above amount, provided for the school at Rabbit Island, be utilized in erecting a building for the Martin Falls band.

Mr. Agent Burk, during a recent visit to the Department, stated that the best means of having the school erected would be that he arrange for the purchase of all materials, from firms on the approved list; and that the labour be performed by Indians, under the supervision of a competent foreman. The Agent estimated the cost of the materials and labour to be about $3,800.00.

It will be necessary to obtain the approval of the Honourable the Superintendent General for the expenditure and secure the names of the firms from whom the building materials should be purchased and also the name of a competent carpenter to act as supervisor of construction. The church authorities are anxious that the school be completed in time for classroom work to begin September first, next.

I therefore beg to recommend that you approve of utilization of the funds provided for the school at Rabbit Island to cover the cost of the work at Martin Falls and also that you request the Architect to make the necessary arrangements to erect the building at an early date.

Dear Mr. Burt:

As you may be aware, the Morrison River Indians have been expected to come and reside on the reserve and send their children to the new school established there. However, they have failed to move here, which has caused some concern among the local residents.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant, file 9-18-1, regarding further prospects of the re-opening of the Martin Falls Indian Day school.

In reply I may say that the reason I did not answer your letter was that this same question was taken up with Mr. P. Phelan on one of my visits to Ottawa, and I pointed out that it would be necessary to wait until the summer of 1939, in order to ascertain if the pulpwood company at Little Long Lao are going to give the Indians pulpwood concessions at the South end of the lake. If these concessions are given to our Indians, it will mean that the two reservations situated at Long Lao will be able to receive continuous work. The Long Lao #53 reserve is situated on the Canadian National Railway. The reserve where the school is situated is approximately four miles from this station. If both of these bands could obtain work away from the railway, they would be far better off.

For the Department's information, I may say that it is very difficult for the Indians to secure work in the vicinity of the town of Little Long Lao, consequently it is hoped that final arrangements can be made this summer to secure work for both of these bands. In the meantime I would strongly recommend that settlement of this question be left until after treaty payment.

With reference to establishing a school during the summer at the Martin Falls school I may say that this question was taken up with the Indians and owing to survey work which was going on last summer, a large percentage of the male members were on survey parties and their families moved with them to the opposite end of the Lake.

In conclusion, I may say that I consider it advisable to go into this question very thoroughly before any definite decision is made. I will be very pleased to report on the above, directly after treaty payments.

Memorandum: MR. PHILAN

Re: Inspection of North Bay, Spanish, Manitoulin Island, Shingwauk Home and Longlac.

LONGLAC

The Longlac new school is a substantial building. Unfortunately, the plan for partitioning could have been greatly improved. It was too late, however, to do anything about the classroom divisions.

The Domestic Science room is a little room, 11' x 18'. As will be noticed it is too small. I have suggested that a partition separating this room from the dispensary be removed which would leave a room 13' x 24'.

There is a good basement but it is too low, the ceiling being only 6½ feet high. The lighting is, consequently, poor.

This school is not yet completed. Material and labor has been a serious handicap. Only one classroom is in operation. This produces crowding and interference as the teachers are working together. This is only a temporary arrangement and by the end of January should be remedied.

There were forty-one pupils enrolled. A number were absent due to sickness. Reverend Father Couture expects an enrolment of about sixty.

Material to teach domestic science has been sent so that this activity may be undertaken without delay. Gardening will be introduced this summer and as the teachers remain there the whole year, I have great hopes that this activity will be a success.

There is a registered nurse who is checking the children very carefully. I understand that she also visits the people on the Reserve.

I have explained to the teachers, the method of the integrated program of study and have asked them to study this system and to endeavour to introduce it gradually. The introduction must necessarily be gradual in order that the teachers themselves may learn this line of work. I am sending them a few reference books which, I believe, will prove helpful.

A.J. Doucet,
Training Division.

Sir:

With reference to estimates for 1935-36, I beg to advise I am enclosing herewith an estimate amounting to $4500.00 for combination school and residence on the Martin Falls Reserve.

I may say the Indians have asked for a school during the past 6 years. Last year the Indians were extremely disappointed that a school was not built.

The Chief has just called at this office and informed me that a meeting was recently held and he was sent up as their representative to go there and provide funds for the purpose of building this school. I may say I have also received a communication from Rev. W. Bradbury, Anglican Missionary, also urging that the school be built. Mr. Bradbury mentioned as the Martin Falls Reserve is the only Protestant one in the Agency he considers they should receive some consideration, as the 7 other schools are Catholic. Mr. Bradbury states there are 35 children of school age on the Reserve. I regret I overlooked including this item in the estimates sent to the Department.

I am also including $400.00 for the construction of a basement and $250.00 for a hot air furnace and cement reservoir for the McIntyre School. On a recent visit to this school I noticed that the school is sagging in 2 different points. There is only a temporary wooden foundation. I regret I overlooked forwarding these items at an earlier date. I trust the Department will recommend same.

Your obedient servant,

J. C. Burk,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sirs:

May I draw your attention to the fact, that the Indians of Martin Falls Reserve, were promised a school. I certainly expected that a school would be built on the Reserve last year, but such was not the case.

I understand, that there are six or seven Indian Catholic Schools, in Port Arthur Agency, and I cannot see, for the life of me, why the only Protestant Reserve cannot have a school.

I may add, that the Chief and Councillors, requested me to write to you on this matter.

Hoping this will meet with your approval,

Yours very truly,

I just heard from Mr.J.G.Burke Indian Agent Port Arthur, who informed me that the Department was going to build a School on the Martin Falls Reserve this year.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill,

The authorities of the Church of England have requested that a day school building, with living accommodation for a teacher, be established for the benefit of the Indian children of the Martin Falls band, residing on Long Lac reserve, No. 77, Fort William agency, Ont. Mr. Agent Burk, Port Arthur, states that the school should provide accommodation for approximately 36 children.

There are no funds specially provided to cover the cost of erecting the building, but there is an amount of $4,000.00 provided in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year, to erect a day school at the Rabbit Island settlement, the Manitoulin Island Unceded Reserve. The need for a school at this point is not as pressing as on the Long Lac reserve, and I would recommend that the above amount provided for the school at Rabbit Island be utilized in erecting a building for the Martin Falls band.

Mr. Agent Burk, during a recent visit to the Department, stated that the best means of having the school erected would be that he arrange for the purchase of all materials, from firms on the approved list, and that the labour be performed by Indians, under the supervision of a competent foreman. The Agent estimated the cost of the materials and labour to be about $3,800.00.

It will be necessary to obtain the approval of the Honourable the Superintendent General for the expenditure and secure the names of the firms from whom the building materials should be purchased and also the name of a competent carpenter to act as supervisor of construction. The church authorities are anxious that the school be completed in time for classroom work to begin September first, next.

I therefore beg to recommend that you approve of utilization of the funds provided for the school at Rabbit Island to cover the cost of the work at Martin Falls and also that you request the Architect to make the necessary arrangements to erect the building at an early date.

With reference to construction of the combined Indian Day School and residence at Long Lake Reserve, which is now under construction, I beg to report I have just received a communication from the foreman, who advises the work is progressing very favourably. I may say the cost of 2 large heaters, one for the residence and one for the schoolroom, including pipes, would not exceed approximately $75.00. The cost of the furnace would not exceed $300.00. Under the circumstances would it be possible to install a new furnace.

Sir:

Please obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost. These, you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment.

Port Arthur, Ont.,
June 17, 1936.

Sir:

May I bring to your attention the location of the Martin Falls School at Long Lac, Ont.

The Reserve on which the school is located is approximately four miles from the C.H.R. station across a small lake and there is no way of reaching the station, Post Office or stores other than by boat. Under the existing circumstances, the teacher advises that she is obliged to pay an Indian for transportation every time she visits the school at Long Lac. A boat can be purchased for this purpose for approximately $75.00. As previously mentioned, owing to the isolation of this school, I would strongly recommend the purchase of a boat for this school.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, June 22, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, requesting that a boat be supplied for the use of the teacher of the Martin's Falls School. It is noted that the school is located approximately 4 miles across a small lake from the C. N. R. station, post office and stores.

It is not the practice of the Department to supply boats for teachers' use. Would the teacher have to row a distance of 4 miles? If so, there is an element of danger in her rowing that distance, in the event of sudden storms on the lake. The school will soon be closed for summer holidays, and, as it is presumed the teacher will not be staying there during the vacation period, there does not appear to be any immediate necessity for supplying a boat. Besides, it is considered that, if a boat is supplied, one could be obtained, satisfactory for the purpose, at a lower cost than $75.00.

The Department would like information regarding the distance across the lake; whether the teacher remains at the school during the holiday period and, also, what arrangements could be made for the proper care and storage of the boat. When we have further information, as requested, consideration will be given as to whether funds for the purpose can be authorized. I may add that we have no special provision for supplying boats for teachers' use.

Yours Truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Attention - School Branch

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 22nd instant relative to previous correspondence regarding the purchase of a boat for the teacher of the Martin Falls Indian Day School at Long Lac, Ont.

The distance from the School to the station at Long Lac is approximately four miles. The teacher, when rowing to and from the Post Office and Store in the village, would always be able to keep within a short distance from the shore.

As this Reserve is isolated and the teacher is the only white person on the Reserve, I would strongly recommend the purchase of a boat to enable the teacher to make contact with the white people in the village at Long Lac, and to enable her to go and come when she so desires. At the present time she is obliged to pay the Indians to convey her to the store and Post Office and to and from the Reserve.

The price of $75.00 includes the freight, and a good substantial boat.

With reference to the teacher taking holidays, I believe she intends spending part of them at Long Lac, but the boat can be stored in the School basement, when she is away.

I trust the Department will see fit to authorize this purchase.

Your obedient servant,

J. J. Clark
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

The attention of the Department has been drawn to the fire hazard in connection with the Martin Falls Indian Day School. It is stated that there are piles of brush within a radius of 25 yards and almost encircling the school.

I would request that you arrange for Indian labour to clean up and remove any brush, trees, etc., for a distance around the school building, in order to overcome any danger of fire. No unnecessary expense should be incurred, and it is thought the Indians should carry out this work without expense for their services. If not, you should forward vouchers, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost. The number of hours employed and the rate paid should be definitely stated. The Department will expect you to see that no unnecessary expense is incurred in cleaning up the grounds at this school.

I have your letter of Sept. 29th, file No. 9-18-1 relative to previous correspondence in connection with the opening of an Indian day school at Longlac, Ont.

As you will no doubt recall, I discussed this matter with you on my recent visit to Ottawa. At the time I mentioned that the Reverence Father J. Couture said he would go into the matter very carefully and advise me at some future date. During my absence from the office, Father Couture called and stated there was no temporary building available at Longlac suitable for a school and has recommended that the school now situated on the Long Lake #77 (Martin Falls) reserve, across the bay, could be moved across the ice (a distance of approx. 4 miles), to the Long Lake #58 reserve, during the winter months.

I have written to Longlac to make enquiries as to the cost of building a basement at L. Lake #58 reserve and moving the building during the winter months, from the M. Falls reserve. When the figures have been obtained I will be very pleased to notify you immediately.

Memorandum: MR. PHELAN

Re: Inspection of North Bay, Spanish, Manitoulin Island, Shingwauk Home and Longlac.

The Longlac new school is a substantial building. Unfortunately, the plan for partitioning could have been greatly improved. It was too late, however, to do anything about the classroom divisions.

The Domestic Science room is a little room, 11' x 12'. As will be noticed it is too small. I have suggested that a partition separating this room from the dispensary be removed which would leave a room 12' x 24'.

There is a good basement but it is too low, the ceiling being only 6½ feet high. The lighting is, consequently, poor.

This school is not yet completed. Material and labor has been a serious handicap. Only one classroom is in operation. This produces crowding and interference as the teachers are working together. This is only a temporary arrangement and by the end of January should be remedied.

There were forty-one pupils enrolled. A number were absent due to sickness. Reverend Father Couture expects an enrolment of about sixty.

Material to teach domestic science has been sent so that this activity may be undertaken without delay. Gardening will be introduced this summer and as the teachers remain there the whole year, I have great hopes that this activity will be a success.

There is a registered nurse who is checking the children very carefully. I understand that she also visits the people on the Reserve.

I have explained to the teachers, the method of the integrated program of study and have asked them to study this system and to endeavour to introduce it gradually. The introduction must, necessarily be gradual in order that the teachers themselves may learn this line of work. I am sending them a few reference books which, I believe, will prove helpful.

A.J. Doucet,
Training Division.

Ottawa, 16 October 1946.

Mr. J.G. Purk, Indian Agent,
PORT ARTHUR, Ontario.

We have your letter of the 9th instant with reference to the Longlac School.

With regard to the amount requested for the proposed Christmas entertainment, you will remember that we discontinued the practice of providing funds for this purpose several years ago. While the individual amounts requested for each school might be considered, by some, as small, the total expenditure for all our schools involved a considerable amount.

In the present instance an expenditure of $39.72 is requested. If you multiply this amount by approximately 300 schools, you will readily realize that it means a heavy expenditure. However, we are in favour of having a Christmas entertainment for the pupils and it has been decided to allow an amount of $20.00 for this school provided the Indians provide a similar amount for their own children. This could be raised by having some type of entertainment in the school for which a small admission would be charged. Please discuss this suggestion with the reverend Sisters and let us hear from you again.

Before considering the amount requested for plates etc., for the pupils noon-day lunch, we would like to know what is being served. While we are willing to assist in supplying some funds for a light lunch at noon, it is felt that owing to payment of family allowances, the children should be in a better position to bring some lunch to school. Besides we do not wish the noon-day lunch to become too elaborate as it involves considerable weaning of dishes and in many cases this means a loss of time from the regular classroom work. We will wait for a further communication from you.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Ottawa, Ontario,
June 6, 1947.

Re: Nursing Station for Long Lac

With reference to previous correspondence concerning this matter, I think we should enquire into the question of moving the school from its present site to the reserve where it could be used as a nursing station. We will have the permission of the Schools Branch of Indian Affairs to do this.

It would be appreciated if you would find out what it will cost to move this building during the coming winter over the ice. It is noted that a previous estimate was $305.00. This estimate was given in 1945 and circumstances may have changed so that it would be of no value at this time.

May we have a report by next fall on this matter and your recommendation so if anything is to be done, arrangements can be made in plenty of time.

[Signature]

V.L. Deaconer, M.D.,
Asst. Director, Indian Health Services.

Referring to your letter of 31st July, on the subject of school desks at the Long Lake Indian Day School, we were informed by the Principal that 12 large and 6 medium size desks will meet their requirements.

The Principal has also drawn my attention to the fact that last school term they were not in receipt of any neatly biscuits. We understand these biscuits were in short supply last year, but it is expected that a surplus will be made available this year for this school inasmuch as they received none last year. The estimated number of pupils to be in attendance this coming term is 50.

We were in receipt of a monthly authorization to spend £9.00 on supplies for the children's noon-day lunch for this school during the last term. The Principal has asked that this be increased, as the attendance will be larger, and the items cost more. We have told the Principal that there is doubt that there will be any increase over the £9.00 in view of the fact that parents can supplement this amount through their family allowance benefits, but would welcome having your views on this matter.
Ottawa, August 12th, 1947.

Mr. J.G. Burk, Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ontario.

With reference to your letter of the 7th instant, the Departmental Purchasing Agent will be requested to secure the desks for the Long Lac School.

Nine hundred pounds of vitaminized biscuits have been ordered for this school. They will probably be delivered during the month of September.

With reference to the last paragraph of your letter, it is considered that the amount previously allowed, namely $8.00 a month for the noon-day lunch should be sufficient. As you state, Family Allowances are being paid for the children attending this school and it is reasonable to suppose that the parents will be financially able to supply some lunch for their children.

Last May we forwarded you an accountable cheque for $500.00 to be spent on road repairs leading from the Long Lac School to the highway. Has this work been done and if so, is it satisfactory?

Bernard T. Henry
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

This Office is in receipt of a request from the Principal of the Long Lake I.D.S. for the authority to purchase $50. for sewing material and $60. for kitchenware.

We are passing on to you our recommendation that an amount of $50. for each purpose be authorized for this season. With the acquisition of these equipment in the past, this school's requirements shall be lessened, and the $50. amount will also provide for the location for local purchase by the Principal.

As we were in receipt of this school's request for this authority last month but could not bring it to your attention for consideration until now owing to pressure of more important matters, your early attention would be welcomed, please.

Ottawa, November 17, 1947.

Mr. J.C. Burk, Indian Agent, Port Arthur, Ontario.

We have your letter of the 5th instant, enclosing an account from Moyer School Supplies for desks shipped to the Longlac Indian Day School.

In your letter you referred to P.O. 22252. In this case, I would point out that the purchase order number was issued to Vilas Furniture Company, Cowansville, Quebec. Evidently, they delivered the eighteen desks as you forwarded voucher No. 1059 dated October 19, 1947 and a cheque for $274.50 has been forwarded to the company. We have no record of having issued a Purchase Order for desks to the Moyer School Supply Company.

Bernard P.J. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Colonel Murray:

Longlac (R.C.) Day School:

This school was visited by me on Nov. 10, the Monday preceding the Remembrance Day holiday. The teachers stated that Monday was usually a day of low attendance and, coming between holidays, Monday, Nov. 10 achieved a new low - 28 out of the enrollment of 50.

The principal emphasized that the allowance of $8 a month lunch money was inadequate. I suggest that it be raised to $10 effective Nov. 47.

She also expressed disappointment at the curtailing of requisitions.

Time permitted only a superficial inspection, but I got the impression that it was a creditable school. It is easily accessible to visitors, being close to the main line of the C.N.R. and to Highway No. 11 from Toronto.

C.A.T. Clark

Mr. Roy,

Dr. Moore asked me yesterday afternoon whether any reorganisation of the Fort Arthur Agency had been planned by the Civil Service Commission. I inquired from Mr. Allan whether there was any report, but Mr. Allan did not know.

Dr. Moore said he had Bishop Landry, Monseigneur Lambert and Father Couture in his office, speaking on behalf of Mr. Burk, stating what a good job he was doing and what a vast territory he had to cover with so little assistance in his office. They were most anxious to know whether something was being done to improve things at this agency.

I phoned Mr. Orr and told him I was inquiring in your absence. He informed me that he had not yet come to any definite conclusions in regard to the Port Arthur Agency, as he had been working on the western agencies, but that the matter would receive consideration in due course. He intimated that it would be decided either to take some of Mr. Burk's Agency away from him and put it into another agency, or give him additional help. I gave this information to Dr. Moore.

While in his office these gentlemen mentioned that there was a school at Martin's Falls (Anglican) which was closed and they wished to have the school transported across the river to Long Lac Reserve to be used as a Clinic and an old people's home. Dr. Moore informed them that he would do whatever work was required to alter the school for the purpose and operate it as a clinic, but that the maintenance of old people was a Welfare matter which would have to be taken up with the Indian Affairs. Dr. Moore asked me to bring this to your attention. I believe that you already have been approached in regard to having the school used as a Clinic.

M. Walton.
February 12, 1948.

Mr. J.O. Burk, Superintendent,
Indian Agency, Port Arthur, Ontario.

His Excellency, Bishop Landry and Father Couture recently discussed with Dr. Moore the possibility of moving the school at Martins Falls to the vicinity of the Long Lac School to be used as a clinic and old peoples' home at the latter place.

In the event of our approving the removing of this school, the Department of National Health and Welfare is prepared to provide the funds for moving it.

Please advise me at once if you consider that such action is desirable and you might comment on the suggestion that the building be used partly as an old people's home. I may say that I have not yet discussed this phase of the proposition with the Welfare Division.

Is there any likelihood that Martins Falls school will be required for school purposes in the immediate future?

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education

PP/IVCD
Port Arthur Indian Agency.

February 23, 1948.

Bernard F. Neary, Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

With reference to your letter of the 12th instant,
file 9-18-5 (L.l), I do not see any possibility of using
the school at Martine Falls for the purpose for which
it was originally intended and I think it would be ad-
visable to move it to Long Lac to be used as a clinic.

J.G. Burk,
Superintendent of Indian Agency.
Longlac, Feb. 25, 1948.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

The old school will start moving across the ice of Long Lake on Monday the first day of March. I suppose that you know already that the contract for pulling that school across the lake has been given for $1,500.00 fifteen hundred dollars, and so the contract will be fulfilled before the end of next week. That is before Saturday the 6th of March.

So we would need the money to pay that contractor at that date Saturday the 6th of March.

Now why is it that Mr. Burk instead of getting a contract for himself, came to Longlac and took my contract as his own and then raised the price? I do not know, I was not here yet at the moment. I did not intend to give so much myself on account of this, that I had good friends here who would furnish the contractor with big tractors and men and drivers, cables and tools, etc. So now the transportation of that building costs me $1,500.00 which is supposed to be paid by the Department.

I have paid already $450.00 to the contractor to help him pay 15 men.

Your very gratefully,

(Signed) J.M. Couture, S.J.
Ottawa, Ontario
March 8, 1948

Dear Father Couture:

We have been asked by Mr. Philip Phelan to answer your letter dated February 25 regarding the moving of the school across the Lake.

The Minister has approved the project provided it be limited to providing the building free, plus the money to cover its removal not to exceed $2500.

It is therefore in order to move the building. All accounts should be forwarded to Mr. Burk, the Superintendent of Indian Agency at Port Arthur, as quickly as possible so that payment may be made promptly.

I do hope the removal of this building will help you in your work.

Yours very truly,

O. Léroux, M.D.
Assistant Director
Indian Health Services

Rev. J. M. Couture, S.J.
Long Lac,
Ontario

Dear Sir:

We are writing in reference to the cupboards we already mentioned in a conversation we had with you at the time of a visit you made at our school.

We looked them in the catalogues and could not find any that would meet with our requirements. However, the carpenters who are building the church are ready to make three of the sizes we need, that is:

1. 10 ft x 6 ft in length
   7" x 6" in height
   24 inches in width

2. 4 ft. in length
   10 feet in height
   24 inches in width

3. 5 feet in length
   7 feet in height
   24 inches in width.

Their charge would be £300. Will you kindly grant us the authorization to have this work started as soon as possible as we would like to have these cupboards finished by the month of September.

Will you also be kind enough to buy a sewing machine for the school as one is not enough to teach all our big girls. Another reason for making this request is that many young women on the reserve very often come to make their trousseau dresses, etc., and they are sorry they cannot sew two together as they very seldom come alone.

Awaiting a favourable reply and thanking you for your kind attention to these request, we remain,

Yours very truly,

"Sister Mary Saint Martha"
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa

I am enclosing herewith a copy of a letter received from the Missionary Sister at Longlao Indian Day School, which is self-explanatory.

Would you kindly advise if authorization can be obtained to carry out this work.

J.G. Burk,
Superintendent.

LONG LAC INDIAN DAY SCHOOL INSPECTION REPORT

Date of inspection: September 25, 1949.

Location of School - This is a two-room school situated at Long Lac, Ontario. It is not a Departmentally owned school but was erected and is owned by the Bishop of Hearst. It was built in 1945 and it is unfortunate that a proper plan was not followed. Both the classrooms are on the ground floor and are poorly lighted. Each has four windows on the outside facing with all placed high in the wall. There are four electric light fixtures in the ceiling and these provide at least a little light. The rooms are wider than longer in relation to the blackboards.

There is a teacher's residence for the Sisters on the second floor of the school. Photographs are attached to this report. We pay a rental of $45 a month for the building.

Teachers

(a) Junior Room - Sister Mary of the Redemption has a first class teaching certificate from the Province of Quebec and has eleven years experience. I observed a handicap less on and noted an air of mild confusion with pupils wandering rather freely around the classroom. The teacher's language is fairly good but the French accent is decided.

(b) Senior Room - There are only 13 children in this room whereas there are 18 children in the junior room. In fact there are hardly enough children to operate two classrooms.

Received yesterday a letter from Mr. John Hagen of Hamilton asking me whether the ladies appointed to teach the schools at Elliot and Seguin are British subjects. It happens that one is, and another one is not.

I wish to explain to you Department how I am obliged to be sure and have always competent teachers for all our Indian Schools. Many years ago my predecessor engaged the services of a Society of teaching ladies for the Industrial School at Wiikumikong (name of the girls). This was the same society that now agreed to take care of our Indian day schools. Last year they took Wiikumikong and Smith Bay, and this year they take also Mat. Bay and Seguin, with the intention of taking the other ones following.

This Society has members and houses in England, in Ireland, in France, in the United States, in Quebec etc., etc. Its members belong to all nationalities. They are sent by their presidents to the different places according to the needs of such places and the abilities of the subjects.

Here at Wiikumikong they give good satisfaction very early, and they are well liked by the Indians. The experience...
of last year at Wikwemikong and South Bay prove that their manner of teaching and of dealing with the Indians is doing an immense good to these people. They go two by two, and the one who is not in charge of the school visits the families, particularly the sick, and spreads gently among them the benefits of a true Christian civilization.

With them there is no danger of seeing any more long interruptions caused by the departure of one teacher and the difficulty of finding another one. Should one be obliged to retire, another one shall be sent at once to take his place.

Your Department is aware of the extreme difficulty, if not the total impossibility of finding competent teachers and study for these missions. The history of the past shows that other teachers, if coming at all, do not remain; and often it becomes necessary to take young novices with no real competency to fill the position rather than to give any proper teaching. It was so much the fact that before the... of the new arrangement I was of opinion that the day-schools were a failure, and that all the money spent for them was lost.

Consequently, for the benefit of the Indians I ask you, dear Sir, to approve officially my doing... grant me the liberty to appoint any lady of this Society, no matter what may be her nationality. I may add that, if it was necessary for these ladies to be British subjects, they are ready...
To undergo all required formalities to become such and be able to devote themselves to the education of the Indians.

Please, dear Sir, answer with no delay, as it is time to start teaching at once.

Your servant in the Lord,

G. A. Oertel

Sir,

The teacher Miss Fagan tells us that she cannot teach in this school because of the sickness of the children and the fact that the school is closed due to the sickness of the children. She also mentions that there are only two pupils registered at the school.

We do not want our school closed or to lose our teacher. There are at present 14 pupils registered.

We have heard that the school will be closed regularly and that some have been sick. We hope that the school will remain open and that the children will be able to attend regularly.

We do not understand why this school should be closed and we urge that it be kept open, where there has been but two children attending, and there are at least six or seven here every day.

Re Schools on the Spanish River Reserve.

During my recent visit to the above reserve I learned on good authority that there were no less than 22 Indian children prepared to attend the Saganock School. The school itself is in perfect order, and is fully capable of accommodating this number. Further than this, every arrangement is on hand for the reception of a teacher, including housekeeping requirements and wood for heating purposes. There is a strong feeling on the reserve that a teacher should, if possible, be supplied.

I also learned that the school situated on the bank of the Spanish River was seldom open for scholars, there being only two who occasionally attend. The Anglican Church minister at Mawney is, I believe, being paid the sum of $450 per annum for teaching this school, and in my opinion it would seem advisable to either have the school regularly open or completely closed, in view of the above circumstances.

The local Indians have a rooted objection to sending their children to the Catholic College at Spanish, claiming that the young boys and girls return from there with very little education, having been for the most of the time occupied while there
at school in the uplifting process of sawing wood
and doing chores.

I beg to inform you that the Toulouses don't want to send their children to school. I went there today to see what was going on.

I'm writing this letter to you because I want you to know how I feel about making all the parents send their children to school. Last year I couldn't make them all come.

I wrote many times to the Indian Agent about it, but he never showed up, and then I wrote to Dept. and then he got a letter from there and he was told to force the children to attend school, and then he never did anything.

The Toultoures didn't want to send their children to school, some of them said, "I'll do with my children as I like." I went to Massay many times to see Edward Besaw the constable for this reserve to help me to make the Toultoures send their children to school, he never did anything. He gets paid from the funds of this reserve, he ought to do something if there was trouble, he wouldn't know it he lives so far and no telephone here.

Besaw only comes here when he brings the Indian Agent. The last time he was here when the Indian Agent was distributing the annuity... may be it would be better a constable to live right on the reserve.
It's about a mile and half from this school house to Toulouse Bay along the shore. Last summer I took men from here to make a little road to Toulouse Bay close along the shore to make it shorter. I only did this for the Toulouse children to use it when they come to school. We didn't finish it through we went over halfway. I told the Toulouses to start from their place to make this little road on that same day we work and they didn't want to do that. and it goes as far as we made it. It's the Toulouses that should have work here.

An early answer to this letter will greatly oblige.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Synopsis of Memorandum to Council of January 11th, 1936.

On the Spanish River No. 5 Indian Reserve, Thessalon Indian Agency, Province of Ontario, there are forty Indian children of school age, whose parents are members of the Roman Catholic Church and who do not attend any school. A school was conducted for these children previous to June 30, 1930, when the Indians removed to a settlement at Sagamook, 5 miles south. Since that date, no facilities have been available for the Indian children in the settlement where the Indians now reside.

The local Indian Agent, the church authorities and officers of this Department who visited the reserve and also the Indian parents strongly urged the establishment of day school facilities. The erection of the building has been completed, at a cost of approximately $5,000, funds for the purpose having been provided in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year, and the authority to proceed with the work and erect the building by day labour, under the charge of a competent foreman - the local Indian Agent to arrange the purchase of materials - was approved by the former Superintendent General.

The yearly cost of conducting the school will be approximately $1,500.00, which includes teacher's salary, fuel, janitor services, supplies and incidental expenses.

It is necessary, under Section 9 (a) of the Indian Act, that authority be obtained from His Excellency in Council for the establishment of the school, and the attached Memorandum to Council is for that purpose only.

Ottawa, March 4, 1937.

Madam:

I have your letter dated February 29th (?), applying for the position as teacher of the Sagamook Indian Day School and stating the qualifications and experience which you possess.

In reply I have to say that the Department has no information of the intention of the present teacher to give up duties at the end of the current school year. We are, therefore, unable to state at the present time if there will be a vacancy for a teacher at this school for the coming school year.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Miss Lucy M. Hass,
Low Bush,
Ont.
I should understand their tendencies, capacities and deficiencies.

I have been teaching the Junior Class of Wikwemikong Day School for two years. I have also taught the Second Class (Typical) Number 30708.

I shall be ever grateful of this favour so granted me.

Yours respectfully,

Rita Trudeau.
Dear Sir,

I hereby make an appeal that I may be taken as teacher at the Spanish River School, on the Spanish River Reserve, for the next term beginning October 1st, for the following reasons:

I am an Indian girl and a member of the Spanish River Band.

My home is located on the Spanish River Reserve.

I am very interested in the children of the Spanish River Reserve and being one of them myself.
Ottawa, May 14th, 1937.

HYD

Dear Madam:-

I have your letter of the 7th instant, applying for a transfer from the Wikwemikong Indian Day School to the Sagamook Indian Day School.

The teacher of the latter school has not intimated any intention of giving up duties and, under these circumstances, the Department is not prepared to consider transferring you to that school.

Yours truly,

H. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Miss Rita Trudeau,
Indian Day School,
Wikwemikong, Ont.
Dear Mr. [Name],

Your books arrived last week, and they have been used a great deal since. I appreciate very much your having sent them.

I distributed medicine to the Indians during the past year. I understand there was compensation for doing this, but I did not receive any. The agent was informed, that as the Anglican school teacher got it, I could not expect to receive it. This was some time ago. Lately Mr. [Name] told me that I was entitled to it, and advised me to write to you about it.

Yours truly,

Ottawa, July 19, 1937.

MEMORANDUM:

Miss Moodie,

I have a letter from Miss H. Kelly, teacher of the Sagameck Indian Day School, in which she requests that she be allowed remuneration for distributing medicines to the Indians.

I understand that the teacher of the Spanish River Protestant School, which is quite close to the Sagameck School, receives payment for similar services.

Might I suggest that each of them be allowed $5.00 a month for this work?
Wikwemikong,
Manitoulin Island,
Ontario,

Mr. O.M. MacKillop of Sudbury is my school Inspector. Last year my Inspector was Mr. F.S. Lewis at present teaching in North Bay Normal School. You may obtain references from these, and from the Secretary of the School Board here Mr. Burton Howe, Massay.

Massey Station, Ont.,
June 23, 1939.

Dear Sir,

I understand that Miss Honoree Kelly, at present teaching in the Indian Reserve near Massey, is resigning her position and therefore wish to make application for the position.

I have an Interim Second Class certificate and a Grade B certificate in Physical Training. I have had two years teaching experience in public schools. Last year I taught at S.S. No. 4, Paconid, Mindoka, Ont. At present I am teaching in S.S. No. 5, Balter, Massey, but this school is being closed.

I am a Roman Catholic. My parish priest is Rev. J.P. Lynch, Kearney, Ont., and I am also well known to Rev. Father Bunyan of Massey.
Ottawa, June 30, 1939.

Dear Madam:

With reference to your letter of the 25th instant, the Department has not received any intimation that Miss H. Kelly intends to give up duties as teacher of the Sagamook Indian Day School.

Under these circumstances, no consideration can be given at the present time to your application for appointment as teacher of this school.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Miss Mary E. Moore,
Massey Station,
Ontario.
